comment._content: Louise Homer: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louise_Homer The baby is apparently Helen Joy Homer (1915-1946), later the first Mrs. William Main Doerflinger, the youngest of the six Homer children. She was always called Joy, but one of her wedding announcements calls her "Miss Helen Joy," and when her older sister Louise married in 1921, the youngest sisters Hester Makepeace Homer and Helen Joy Homer are listed as her flower girls. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60710F83A5B11728... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anne_Homer Joy Homer had an eventful short life: she was a medical relief worker in China, wrote a memoir of her harrowing journey on foot (Dawn Watch in China), edited Woody Guthrie's Bound for Glory, worked for the OSS in New Delhi during WWII; while in India, she was hurt in a car accident, and she eventually died from her injuries. She's buried in New York: www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~nywarren/cemeteries/bolton.htm

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/11418107@N02]  I'm just reading Joy Homer's book and she was a newspaper reporter in China and was apparently financed by some newspaper / media, but also offered reports to US papers as a freelancer. She didn't intent to write a book at first. She also says she was educated at Smith College, and that she was in London before and worked with "slum dwellers" there (she mentions this comparing them with the Chinese coolis). Do you have more information about her?

comment.author: 59604045@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/11418107@N02] Talking about it I found this orbituary: fultonhistory.com/newspaper%2010/Glens%20Falls%20NY%20Pos... Which is actually a bit wrong about her China experience - she went there in the winter of 1938 or ever 39 - definately she writes about her first adventures there taking place in December, she actually arrived in November I think. And she was just accompanied for a large part of her journey by an American doctor, "Skipper" Brown", who is a relief worker.
